Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Powder X-ray Diffractometer for Nanotechnology and Energy Research and Teaching
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Judy Westrick from Wayne State University and colleagues Stephanie Brock, Ratna Naik, Eranda Nikolla and Charles Winter will acquire an X-ray diffractometer for the study of powdered samples. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. A powder diffractometer also allows compositional analysis. The studies described here will impact a number of areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of chemistry, physics and engineering and materials science students.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) understanding structure-function-size relationships in nanoscale transition metal phosphides and arsenides with magnetic and catalytic functionality; (b) preparing solid-state devices with applications in energy and the environment; (c) studying the effect of size on the phase-transformation temperature of MnAs; (d) developing and growing of thin films; (e) developing heterogeneous catalysts for biomass conversion and electrocatalysts; (f) studying heterogeneous catalyst for biomass conversion; (g) developing multifunctional electrodes for Li-air batteries; (h) establishing applications of in-situ XRD for battery materials characterization; and (i) investigating lattice deformations at multiferroic transitions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Powder/thin film X-ray diffraction is a material characterization technique that enables researchers to determine physical properties (phase identification and transformations, lattice parameters, crystallinity, expansion tensors, crystal structure refinement, etc.) of powders, nano-materials, and polycrystalline thin films.  High sensitivity, good resolution, ambient atmosphere and temperature control are instrument attributes needed to fully characterize materials and nanomaterials for energy, environmental, medical and structural applications. The Bruker D8 Advance DaVinci powder/thin film X-ray diffractometer (XRD) has 1) two radiation sources (Mo and Cu) to provide X-rays of different penetrating power; 2) a 2nd generation linear strip detector; 3) a stage for air sensitive samples; 4) a stage for characterization at temperatures between -193 and 900 ºC; and 5) in situ X-ray diffraction studies on electrode and battery materials. This instrument plays a crucial role to maintaining and advancing WSU’s competitive, cutting edge research in the areas of nanotechnology, material science, chemistry, physics, and engineering.

The acquisition of this instrument facilitates research projects in research groups from Physics, Chemistry, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, and Mechanical Engineering. The data from this instrument enables researchers to evaluate potential applications of materials and nanomaterials. The X-ray diffractometer provides first order and higher order material characterization of: 1) nanoparticles (Prof. Brock); 2) thin films grown by atomic layer deposition (Prof. Winter); 3) nanomaterials-by-design approach (Prof. Rabuffetti); 4) new and advanced structural materials (Prof. Putatunda); 5) heterogeneous catalysts and electrocatalysts for biomass conversion and energy storage (Prof. Nikolla); and 6) new materials for the next generation energy storage systems and batteries (Prof. Nikolla).

The proposed instrument provides users with results that cannot be achieved through other available instrumentation on campus, and it has a broad impact in the advancement of nanoparticles, nanomaterials, and thin films being integrated into the next generation of research projects and commercial products.  Scientific results from these projects are disseminated in peer-reviewed publications and presentations.  Powder/thin film X-ray diffraction workshops and training are available for faculty, post-doctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students, and scientists from regional institutions and industry. The new instrument is being used in graduate and undergraduate lecture/laboratory courses including Intermediate Inorganic Chemistry II and Introduction to Materials Science.  These courses are taken by Chemistry, Physics, and Engineering students. The X-ray Crystallography Laboratory is frequently involved in community education programs for area middle and high schools. For example, Prof. Brock teaches and mentors 7th grade girls (Go-Girl Go Nano) in making ferrofluids.  The PXDR with high count rate allows the performance of real-time demonstrations and develop hands-on experiments for high school students and teachers as part of Wayne State University outreach mission.
